headline.main: Tending to Obesity, Inbred Tribe Aids Diabetes Study; Inbred Tribe Aids Research Into Obesity and Diabetes Samples Are Preserved 6,000 Involved in Study

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody article on results of ongoing study involving researchers from many institutions in US and abroad, that is expected to help unravel genetic and other complexities of diabetes and obesity; study focuses on highly inbred Pima tribe in Arizona, whose adult members are grossly obese and have high rate of diabetes; Dr Peter Bennett and Dr William Knowler comment; some 6,000 Pima Indians are involved in project in hope that accumulating knowledge might benefit their children; illus; map; charts (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: SACATON, ARIZ. THE Pima Indians, whose oncefertile river valley was reclaimed by desert a century ago after white settlers upstream diverted their water, are helping medical researchers unravel the genetic and other complexities of two of the nation's most common ailments --obesity and diabetes.
